results.title: Planet of the apes
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Arthur P. Jacobs, Mort Abrahams, APJAC Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Charlton Heston and two other astronauts come out of deep hibernation to find that their ship has crashed. Escaping with little more than clothes, they find that they have landed on a planet where men are pre-lingual and uncivilized, while apes have learned speech and technology and use the primitive humans for experimentation and sport. Taylor (Heston) is captured and taken to the city of the apes after damaging his throat so that he is silent and cannot communicate with them. But with the help of a benevolent chimpanzee scientist (Roddy McDowall), Taylor escapes their leathery clutches only to be confronted by a chilling fate. Interesting Note: During breaks in filming, actors made up as different ape species tended to hang out together—-apes with apes, orangutans with orangutans, chimps with chimps. It wasn’t required, it just naturally happened. Includes 25 minutes “Making Of” program.

results.title: Plain sailing
results.creator_credit: Martin Cohen, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Designed to assist the small businessman by emphasising the necessity of a thorough knowledge and planning before embarking on a business venture. Describes some of the do’s and don’ts that can make or break a business.

results.title: Pleure Pas la Bouche Pleine = Don't Cry with Your Mouth Full
results.brief_description:
Annie and Frederic, aged 16 and 19 respectively, are courting during summer in Poitou. Secretly, Annie yearns for some more excitement and when Alexandre, superficially more sophisticated than the local boys, comes to Poitou, she gets it. Fragile and charming, this is a female rites of passage film, played in the context of happy family relationships and everyday people. Thomas brings to the whole enterprise an observant eye for the details of village life.

Credits: Director, Pascal Thomas ; writers, Pascal Thomas, Roland Duval, Suzanne Schiffman ; photography, Colin Mounier ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Annie Cole, Frederic Duru, Jean Carmet, Christiane Chamaret, Bernard Menez, Daniel Ceccaldi.

results.title: Pleasure faire
results.creator_credit: Kris Paterson, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From British Columbia, a day at a youth festival reminiscent of the folk fairs of medieval times, organised by people who choose to live outside the usual social pattern. The Pleasure Faire offered crowds a wide variety of hand-made objects—jewellery, beadwork, leatherwork, art, pottery. More than that, it provided a day of music, minstrel songs, dancing, and people participating in the spirit of the occasion, free of any commercialism or constraint. A day of joy, relived through the film.

results.title: Pleasantville
results.creator_credit: Gary Ross, Steven Soderbergh, Robert J. Degus, Jon Kilik and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Dejected teenager David (Tobey Maguire) suffers all the complexities of 90s adolescence. Confronted by doomsaying school teachers and dwindling job prospects, David seeks refuge in his favourite TV show - an old-fashioned, black and white sitcom called Pleasantville. One fateful night a mysterious TV repairman transports David and his precocious sister Jennifer (Reese Witherspoon) inside the fantastic world of Pleasantville, where life is a curious routine of niceties and home-spun values. But the pair’s arrival turns everyday life on its head for the small town, until now untouched by concepts of sex, rebellion, and most notably, colour. An insightful satire of the American Dream, Pleasantville combines pioneering photographic techniques with a stellar cast including Joan Allen, J.T. Walsh, William H. Macy, Jeff Daniels and comic legend Don Knotts as the elusive TV repairman.

results.title: Playtime [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jacques Tati, Rene Silvera and Specta Films
results.brief_description: The third of Tati’s films to feature the gangling form of Monsieur Hulot, “Playtime” is a surreal, comic vision of mankind’s battle against the overwhelming depersonalisation of modern city life. Filmed upon one of the most ambitious and imaginative sets ever to grace the screen, Tati’s cinematic magnum opus took three years and a reported one million pounds to shoot. The result is a startling triumph acclaimed by the international media as Tati’s finest work. Also available on VHS [302002].

results.title: Playing the environment game
results.creator_credit: Mick Csaky and Pictures That Move
results.brief_description: One of London’s outstanding features is the historic architecture, and this film shows three groups of people fighting changes, including developers against community groups. The process of corporate land acquisition is illustrated, and the effects of this on local residents and council plans for land.

results.title: Playing for time
results.creator_credit: Daniel Mann, Linda Yellen and Syzygy Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the memoirs of Fania Fenelon in her book The Musicians of Auschwitz and written for television by Arthur Miller, this feature length program stars Vanessa Redgrave in the role of Fenelon, a French-Jewish cabaret singer who was working in Paris at the time of the Nazi invasion and who was eventually shipped off to the Nazi death camp in Auschwitz in 1944. Fenelon, along with several other women musicians, is forced to perform for the condemned inmates facing the gas chamber in exchange for her own survival. As long as the group keep performing so their lives are spared and no more aware of this is their leader Alma Rose (Jane Alexander). Conflict and tension increases between these two women as each explores their soul and conscience in this inhumane and degrading struggle for life. For the viewer it raises many issues of the human condition and what price survival but perhaps more controversial is the fact that Vanessa Redgrave is well-known for her anti-Zionist stance, causing wide opposition by many including the real-life Fenelon, to Redgrave’s appearance in the film. However Redgrave puts in a magnificent performance winning her an Emmy Award, along with Emmy Awards for scriptwriter Arthur Miller, supporting actress Jane Alexander, and Oustanding Dramatic Special Award for the film itself. Cast also includes Maud Adams, Shirley Knight, Marisa Berenson, Robin Bartlett, Mady Kaplan. A compelling and poignant story.

results.title: Playing Fair
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A series of four dramas for 7-12 year olds intended to promote discussion on the issues of racism, respect and equality for children. Each episode revolves around a conflict where a child is taunted and discriminated against because they are a member of a minority group. The situations are credible and expose the impact of such behaviour on children.

group_works.title: Walker

results.title: Walker
results.creator_credit: Alanis Obomsawin, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Walker is a young American Indian boy who has tragically lost his parents and is now fostered by another American Indian family. His only playmate and real companion is his dog. Jamie, a lonely young white boy has been made afraid, not only of dogs, but of people who are not white. Walker ignores the racist taunts and jeerings of the older boys who have influenced Jamie, and reaches out to him. Together they find friendship and understanding as Jamie learns to conquer his fears.
